title: symptoms new covid omicron xe
story: Symptoms of new Covid Omicron XE iant as over  cases detected in UKThe new Covid XE iant has symptoms which are more cold like and whilst the disease is similar to Omicron - it is reported to be % more transmissible than other strainsThe new iants symptoms can include a runny nose, sneezing and sore throats Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByKaisha LangtonAssistant News EditorLiam Buckler:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsThe latest symptoms of the new Covid XE iant are believed to be more like a cold with runny noses and sneezing most commonly reported. The new iantaposs symptoms can include a runny nose, sneezing and sore throats - with the symptoms having changed since the original virus which contained coughs and fevers and a lost of smell or taste.The new iant, however, is similar to Omicron and most who have reported symptoms are believed to have cold-like symptoms.However, although little is known of Covid XE at this stage, many believe it does not come with any new symptoms. The new iant was identied in mid-January with more than  cases identied in the country so far. What are the new symptoms of Covid XE  Colds, coughs, running nose and a sore throat are most likely to be Covid XE symptoms.The new iant Covid XE is a mutation of the Omicron BA. and BA. strains - and is referred to as a recombinant. As Covid iants meet they multiply and evolve by sharing their genome or characteristics, therefore ending up with a recombinant. However, the virus is more likely to spread as it has reported to be % more transmissible than other strains. Meanwhile, the most recent data from UK public health officials finds that the new strain only accounts for % of cases in Britain. Thankfully, health bosses do not believe this iant is more severe than its predecessors with the vaccine holding up the barrier against the virus successfully. According to the World Health Organizationhas said early tests indicated XE is around % more transmissible - but the body has added the findings need more investigation.  The WHO report published last week said: Early-day estimates indicate a community growth rate advantage of % as compared to BA., however this finding requires further confirmation. “XE belongs to the Omicron iant until signicant dferences in transmission and disease characteristics, including severity, may be reported.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CoronavirusOmicron iant" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily health briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: team gb olympic sprinter wins
story: Team GB Olympic sprinter Emma Ania wins court battle with bigamist dads fourth weEmma Ania, a former GB Olympic m runner, has won a court fight over a house with her bigamist dads fourth we but is left with nothing after the six year battleSprinter Emma Ania won the court battle over the house Image: Champion NewsByPaul KeoghSara Odeen-Isbister:,  Apr |comments A Team GB Olympic sprinter has won a court fight over a house with her bigamist dadaposs fourth aposweapos.But m runner Emma Ania has been left with nothing after the six-year inheritance battle swallowed up all the value in her late father Austin Aniaaposs home. The sprinteraposs dad died aged  in , having married four dferent women, but only ever orcing one of them. He had not made a will, leading to a bitter fight between his fourth aposweapos Florence Ania, Olympian daughter Emma and her mum, Patricia Ania, over his east London home. Judge Nigel Gerald ruled retired nurse Florence was only in a marriage of convenience with Austin and found that Emma and her mum donapost have to hand her a single penny. But the court heard that Emma, who competed for Team GB in the  Olympics - has also been left with nothing because of the costs of fighting with her aposstepmum.apos  Emma Ania, now , was a successful athlete and was part of the British team which failed to complete the  x m relay final at the Beijing Olympics in  following a baton handover mishap. She missed out on London  due to injury, but has since gone on to forge a successful career as a personal trainer. She was one of nine children which her father had with his first two wives, Mary, who he later orced, and Emmaaposs mum Patricia. He married Patricia in  and separated in , but despite not going through a orce went on to marry a younger woman, Toyin, two years later. That marriage also failed, but again he failed to orce before marrying his fourth aposweapos, Florence, in , meaning Patricia was his last lawful we. Mr Ania had suffered with ill health for much of his adult le and died in , sparking a fight over his home in Leyton, east London.  Following a trial at Central London County Court last year, Judge Gerald threw out claims by both Florence and Patricia that they were entitled to the house, which was in Mr Aniaaposs name. Giving judgment, he said emotions have run particularly high between the warring parties, with Patricia and Emma taking a very strong dislike to Florence. The combined view of the defendants is that Florence is an imposter, essentially, who entered into a civil marriage of convenience with [Mr Austin] and has sought to take advantage of his frailty and advanced years to get money out of the estate, he said. Florence, on the other hand, regards herself very much as the wronged woman because it is her position that when she married the deceased she did so in good faith, not knowing that he was already married and therefore was entering into a bigamous marriage. Although they had married at Haringey Registry Office in , Mr Ania and Florence had never been a genuine couple, the judge found. Their marriage was simply a way for Nigerian-born Florence, who had had an asylum claim rejected, to get permission to stay in England.Florence, who had claimed to have sacriced  years of my le to care for Mr Ania, had told a straight lie, he said. They had not married in a tribal ceremony in Nigeria, but only in a civil ceremony in London to help her stay in the UK. At no time did Florence regard herself as having anything other than a fake marriage or marriage of convenience with the deceased, he found. Florence and the deceased connived to concoct the marriage of convenience purely and solely to enable Florence to remain in the United Kingdom because her asylum claim was bound to fail, because it was based on a tissue of lies. Not only did she willingly participate in the  civil marriage, knowing that it was not genuine, but there never had been any tribal marriage, so giving the lie to her claim that the civil marriage was a renewal of vows. However, because Mr Ania had provided a home for her in his final years, she had been dependent on him and so was entitled in principle to a payout from his estate under the  Inheritance Act, he added.  But the case went back to court this week after Florence claimed that the Leyton house had been deliberately sold below its true value in order to defeat her claim to a payout. Although an expert had valued the property at £,, Emma and Patricia as administrators of the estate had sold it for only £,, leaving nothing to fund a payout to Florence after estate debts were paid. For Patricia and Emma, barrister Stephen Boyd denied that the property had been deliberately sold at an undervalue to avoid having to give Florence a penny, pointing out that would harm them too as they were due to inherit most of the estate. Patricia was the main beneficiary under intestacy rules and had intended for the house to be her family home, but had to sell it because she could not get a mortgage to fund the £, needed to refurbish and extend it, he said. A deal had then been agreed with an Icelandic businessman to purchase the house for £,, reduced to £, only because they had been unable to get Florence to leave first so it could be sold empty. Giving judgment, Judge Gerald said the £, valuation was not reliable, given the appalling state of the property, its sitting squatter Florence and the fact that it was effectively a forced sale. He said mother and daughter had been placed in the position of having to sell due to unpaid debts owed by Florence from a previous court case relating to the validity of her marriage with Mr Austin. It seems to me very dficult to challenge the integrity of the decision which Patricia and Emma made to enter into this contract, he said at the end of a four-day trial this week. There is, in my judgment, nothing surprising or untoward in the acts, conduct and behaviour of Patricia and Emma, as administrators, or the third party purchaser. There is no evidence of any nature whatsoever of any untoward collusion. In many respects, Patricia and Emma were put in the position of a forced sale. The judge said Florence had made largely bogus claims during the case, including an off-the-cuff accusation that Emma, who lives in Belgium, and the Iceland-based purchaser are in a relationship, simply because she had been told Emma had a white boyfriend. He continued: Now that the property has been sold and the proceeds largely spent, from the estate accounts I have been provided with it is quite plain that the estate has negative assets. Her claim under the  Act must fail, because there was no money. It must follow that the claim must be dismissed. Ordering her to now leave the house so that the new owner can take possession, he said Florence is a squatter with no legal right to remain there. You have got  days before you have to get out of the house, Iaposm afraid, he told her. You will have to contact the local authority. Speaking afterwards, Emma Ania said she hoped the family could now put the six-year battle behind them. title: vets call ban flat faced
story: Vets call for ban on flat-faced puppies in Australia as they grow up suffering in painAnimal rights activist, Rosemary Elliott, argues for a ban on breeding flat-faced dogs in Australia, following one owner who spent £, on le-saving surgeries for her bulldogArticial selection could see healthier bulldogs in the future Image: Getty Images Tetra images RFByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Apr |comments Vets, dog owners and activists have called for a ban on the breeding of flat-faced breeds as they struggle to live with physical deformities.Sentient, a veterinary institute for animal ethics, is one of many animal rights groups pushing for change in Australia. Pugs, Boston terriers and British bulldogs are all bred for their aposcuteapos faces, but struggle to walk, breathe and sleep as a result.President Rosemary Elliott says dogs and cats of these breeds face lelong health conditions, reports Daily Mail.Breeding flat-faced dogs and cats is responsible for animal suffering that is entirely preventable and should be banned in animal welfare legislation, Dr Elliott told a parliamentary hearing in NSW on Thursday. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. These animals suffer gross physical deformities that make everyday le unbearably stressful. She believes there should be a change in legislation, so breeders are required to have certication issued by vets confirming the animals donapost have any health problems. Discussing whether these breeds have a right to live, Dr Elliott said: Their basic existence is one of suffering. We wouldnapost intentionally bring into the world, regardless of species, iniduals who are going to suffer to the extent that many of these animals suffer, she explained. Supporting Dr Elliottaposs viewpoint is Sydney vet, Sam Kovac, who believes gentle articial selection methods could see healthier breeds in a few generations time. I do support modying breed standards to make a healthier Frenchie that needs less vet visits, he said.  One French bulldog owner, Maureen Elvy, from Sydney, has spent over £, on le-saving surgeries for her pet, Phoebe. Phoebe is allergic to  types of trees and can only survive with a diet of crocodile meat and hypoallergenic biscuits. Had Maureen known her costs of living would be so high, she admits she probably wouldnapost have gotten Phoebe - but she has no regrets. What a moral dilemma, I love her so much and I canapost imagine my le without her, she said. But I wouldnapost knowingly get a sick dog. Based on her own experience, Maureen wants to see dodgy breeders prosecuted and where appropriate, be made to pay for treatment for poorly pets.Do you have a dog story to tell  Contact nia.dalton@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: burger king customer sues over
story: Burger King customer sues over Whopper size as he insists ads make it look biggerFast food fan Walter Coleman says he has proof the signature Whoppers sold at Burger King are actually % smaller than what is portrayed in the companys advertisingOne fed up fast food fan says Burger King must be held accountable for its misleading ads Image: Getty ImagesBySam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Apr |comments A furious fast food fan claims heaposs been told a Whopper - and is suing Burger King over of the size of their signature sandwich.Hungry Walter Coleman says the chain advertise their world famous burgers as large and satisfying. But in a lawsuit against the giants, he claims a real Whopper is actually anything but.Legal papers claim that the burger is actually % smaller than portrayed in the companyaposs adverts.Coleman and countless others say they felt cheated when they discovered the actual size of their grub. Now he is demanding Burger King be held accountable for allegedly misleading the public.  The lawsuit, filed last week in the US District Court in Southern Florida, claims that Burger King is misrepresenting the size of its food in its ads. Customers are continually duped into buying a substandard product, it states. In addition to damages, the lawsuit also demands that Burger King “correct the deceptive behaviour.”Burger King advertisements portray the company’s burgers with “oversized meat patties and ingredients that overflow over the bun to make it appear that the burgers are approximately  per cent larger in size, and contain more than double the meat,” the lawsuit reads. “Burger King’s advertisements for its burger and menu items are unfair and financially damaging consumers as they are receiving food that is much lower in value than what was promised. A spokesperson for the restaurant said: “Burger King does not comment on pending or potential litigations.” It is not the only legal action the company has faced when it comes to the burgers.  A group of disgruntled vegan fast food fans filed a lawsuit after Burger King were found to be cooking their meatless Impossible Burgers on the same grill as their beef patties. The class-action lawsuit was filed by Phillip Williams, who says as a result of Burger King’s cooking methods, his supposedly meat-free meal was contaminated by meat by-products. According to the lawsuit: Burger King has no disclosures on its menu that would noty a consumer prior to the purchase of the Impossible Whopper that it was cooked in a manner that would result in meat by-products on the burger. title: doctor shares eye trick reduce
story: Doctor shares eye trick to reduce stress – and it works wonders within secondsDr Karan Rajan who works for the NHS has shared a top tip on social media for how to reduce stress using your eyes and he claims it will start to work wonders in a few secondsDr Karan Rajan shared his tips Image: Jam Press @dr.karanrByBrogan-Leigh HurstShowbiz Reporter:,  Apr |comments TikTok fans have gone crazy after a doctor revealed a simple hack to reduce stress using your eyes. An NHS surgeon named Dr Karan Rajan shared a surprising method with his .million followers, which left many gobsmacked.Dr Rajan - who is a surgeon and lecturer at the University of Sunderland - says his method works within seconds. In a short video clip, he explains how our eyes arenapost connected to our brain and our eyes are part of our forebrain. The doctor went on to tell fans that while working on computers or scrolling through social media, we lose focal vision. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here. He said when we focus on something, our vision narrows and it activates the nervous system - which causes stress. The surgeon said thatwe switch our focal vision to panoramic vision and engage our peripheral vision, it can reduce stress. He gave looking up at the sky as an example. In the comments section, many people agreed with his strategy and thanked him for sharing. Explaining the logic behind this, he says that panoramic and peripheral vision activates the parasympathetic nervous system – the rest and digest response – which decreases arousal. Dr Rajan signed off his video by suggesting taking a few minutes every day to focus on un-focusing to help find relaxation.One person commented: Iaposve started looking at the stars. Sounds sad but itaposs so relaxing. Literally switches off the stress. Another person wrote: Ahhhh. Hence walks in nature work wonders. A third joked: Eye had no idea the Iaposs were part of the brain!And a fourth commented: Ooh I do this while driving, helps me stop panicking. Another shocked viewer said: Wow I’ve done this since being a really little kid, it’s great getting a good doctor reinforcement of my ways. A final person shared: Is this why I feel more relaxed when just gazing at the sky. When I’m anxious I look at the sky I feel calm soon after. Dr Karan responded: Must be!Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@mirrorRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON StressViralLe hacks" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dozens enormous megalithic jars unearthed
story: Dozens of enormous megalithic jars unearthed at mystery archaeological site in IndiaRanging from one to three meters tall, some of the mysterious ancient jars have decorative carvings and others are plain, according to the study coauthor Nicholas SkopalDozens of enormous megalithic jars have been unearthed at an archaeological site in India Image: Tilok ThakuriaByCharlie Duffield:,  Apr |comments Dozens of megalithic jars have been discovered in Assam, India, at four new sites, a new study published in the Asian Archaeology journal has found.Ranging from one to three metres tall, some of the jars have decorative carvings and others are plain, according to the study coauthor Nicholas Skopal, a doctoral candidate at Australia National University in Canberra. Whilst  jars have been identied so far, itaposs thought many more could be buried underground. Itaposs still unknown where they were made and which civilisation used them. Before Skopalaposs  excavation, the megalithicjars had been found on seven known sites, and Brits had discovered some near the Assam site in the s. When excavating the areas surrounding three of these sites, they discovered four more sites with partially exposed jars. Skopal told CNN : By going out, surveying and documenting them properly, the government and universities can manage their heritage a lot better and preserve these jars for future generations.But when the research team found the jars, the majority of their contents had disappeared. There are oral historical accounts of the Naga, local villagers, pulling beads and other items out of the jars - and some locals still have the beads as family heirlooms. In one of the villages weaposre staying in, one of the elderly ladies actually showed methat had been pulled out of the jar, he said. In Laos, similar types of jars have been excavated, with artefacts still contained inside such as beads and human remains. Skopal hopes his team will soon find some unopened jars at the new sites in Assam. He said: Some of the buried ones might have things still inside, but we havenapost excavated yet. To understand when the artefacts were buried, Skopalaposs team intends to use optically stimulated luminescence or OSL - a dating method which involves taking a sediment sample from directly underneath the jar, to determine when the light last hit it. The date would indicate when the the jars were buried, helping archaeologists to better understand exactly when the jars were created. story: Man stunned when his dog lands £ speeding ticket driving on motorwayThe driver in Germany was left speechless after ripping open a letter for a speeding ticket in the mail, to find a photo of his small pet dog sat behind the wheelThe driver was so confused opening the letter Image: @armendaus TwitterByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Apr |commentsWe are all familiar with that sinking feeling you get when you realise youaposve been fined for speeding - but usually, you can only blame yourself. This wasnapost the case for one man in Germany, who opened the letter to find a dferent perpetrator sat behind the wheel.And the offender was his small white dog. The nephew of the driver told The Dodo : My first reaction was: aposThat canapost be real.apos I think my uncle was just as surprised.The letter was stamped with a £ speeding fine, and the image captured his dog facing forwards driving the car. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. He confirmed the image was actually real, but although it appeared the dog was driving the vehicle, he obviously wasnapost. Turns out, the uncle was in charge of the wheel, and his dog was riding alongside him. The exact moment they passed the traffic camera, the pup hopped onto his lap. Normally, the dog wears a special car belt for the safety, the nephew explained. That day, my uncle forgot to put it on him, and the dog came to cuddle him [as he was driving]. The funny part is, he was in his lap for just three seconds. But it was long enough for the dog to be papped. His uncle could have contested the speeding ticket, arguing a lack of proof that it was him driving - but he went ahead and handled the fine himself anyway. He paid it, the nephew said. But I canapost tell you what the authorities thought. This pup isnapost the only one caught in the act - one impatient dog has been captured ringing their doorbell to be let inside.Pooch Diamond, from Alaska, USA, was hilariously filmed buzzing the bell outside her front door. After getting bored of waiting for her owners, she looks towards the Vivint video camera and jumps up. She presses the bell with her paw and sits back down in front of the door, expecting it to open. When there is no answer, she leaps back up and goes again. Her owner, Dorian Davis, said: Unfortunately the cameraaposs didnapost pick up us letting her in. title: mum frustrated nursery refuses replace
story: Mum frustrated as nursery refuses to replace babys shoes despite throwing one awayA mum has demanded a nursery pay to have her daughters shoes replaced after they accidentally threw one away while cleaning - but theyve refused to admit faultThe mum wants the shoes replaced by the nurseryImage: Getty ImagesByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Apr |commentsAs any parent will tell you, kids can be nightmares when it comes to misplacing items - especially when theyaposve been staying at a friendaposs house or just happen to have dropped something somewhere, with no idea where it might have gone.But one mum online has been left fuming after her daughter came home from nursery with just one of her shoes, after it transpired that nursery workers had been having a huge clear out in which they must have accidentally thrown away the other shoe. And while the workers themselves were happy to fund a new pair of shoes out of their own pockets to apologise for the mishap, the mum believes itaposs the nursery who should pay. In her post on Mumsnet, she explained: Our one-year-old came home from nursery with only one of her two very first shoes. The nursery was expecting Ofsted the next day so had had a huge clearout. They have subsequently searched high and low and emailed all the parents.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Theyaposre a lovely nursery, our baby is happy there and weaposre really lucky with our babyaposs key workers. They have both contacted us and offered to buy her a new pair together, which is really kind. However, we emailed the nursery, concerned that they appeared to be having to do so out of their own money, when we thought it was something that the nursery should pay, as a company, rather than what would be an houraposs wage for two of their employees. Especially as one is very junior and the other is pregnant. The mum has since received a reply from the nursery stating they would not pay for the shoes as it isnapost their policy - leaving the mum frustrated that she now has to buy a new pair herself. She added: Nursery have replied, telling us to clearly label our babyaposs clothes and that it isnapost their policy to pay for missing property, as it isnapost with other nurseries or schools.  I get that with schools when the children are responsible for their own things and I would never assume so with clothes, bags or coats etc, but shoes  I also donapost really see how labelling would have helped in this case. Iaposm just sad weaposve lost one of her very first shoes, sad that we might have to buy more unnecessarily given our financial situation, and frustrated that it doesnapost feel like the nursery is valuing their staff or responsibilities. The post sparked debate in the comment section, with other mums split on what they would do in a similar situation. Some said agreed that the nursery should replace the shoes that they lost, but others noted that young children are prone to losing or ruining shoes and clothes, so it shouldnapost come as a surprise that a shoe was misplaced in the first place. One person said: They lost the shoe and should replace it! While another added: The nursery should pay, not the staff. I wouldn’t be asking for a new hoodie every day but [not paying for] a pair of shoes when they admit they were tidying up for Ofsted is wrong. But someone  disagreed, stating: Send your child to nursery in things that you wonapost be botheredtheyaposre stained or lost. Itaposs not great they lost the shoe, but I wouldnapost expect them to replace it. aposinstantapos bond with a manatee is being hailed as a real-le Disney movie - as footage shows the unlikely aposbest palsapos staring longingly at each other. title: stadium leaves sports fans perplexed
story: Stadium leaves sports fans perplexed by selling ridiculous burger for £,A stadium in the United States is selling a burger for £,to commemorate the Atlanta Braves  World Series title - but fans arent convinced its worth the price-tagA stadium in the US is charging a fortune for a special burger Image: Icon Sportswire via Getty ImagesByBrogan-Leigh HurstShowbiz Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr  to commemorate the Atlanta Braves  World Series title - but fans arent convinced its worth the price-tag" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Burger-that-Braves-are-selling-for-.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" to commemorate the Atlanta Braves  World Series title - but fans arent convinced its worth the price-tag" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Burger-that-Braves-are-selling-for-.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" to commemorate the Atlanta Braves  World Series title - but fans arent convinced its worth the price-tag" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Burger-that-Braves-are-selling-for-.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"|commentsA baseball stadium in America is selling an incredibly expensive burger for a whopping £, . The unique burger is intended to commemorate the Atlanta Bravesapos  World Series title and has caused a stir on social media, with many people sharing their thoughts.For the hefty price tag, the burger includes a lot of fancy ingredients, including a Wagyu beef patty, pan-fried eggs, foie gras, lobster tail, Tillamook cheddar cheese, truffle aioli and an heirloom tomato. It also comes with a side of parmesan waffle fries.There are two iants of the burger - the cheaper option costs £the price of which is in reference to the  years the Braves have existed. It comes with a replica  World Series ring.  The far pricier burger costs £,and comes with a limited edition championship ring.A number of Twitter users were baffled by the price of the burger, with some branding it ridiculous.One person wrote: Iaposll be putting out a gofundme to buy this burger at the next braves game. A second shared: Who asked for this  A third added: How many do you think they will sell  Iaposm a foodie and love that baseball has unique menu items, but Iaposm not paying . for this. Iaposm probably not spending more than . or so. Like everything about this is awful, a fourth commented. Someone  shared: First of all you paying over a hundred for tickets second why would I pay this much for a frozen wagyu patty. However, not everyone was opposed to the idea of the burger, with some fans really excited to try it. One encouraged: You gotta try it ONCE! caposmon! Another agreed, adding: This weekend going to give it a try!! The Braves won their first World Series title since  last November, defeating the Houston Astros in four out of six games. After their victory, star player Freddie Freeman said: Iaposm still numb. I donapost really have emotions. Iaposm kind of trying to tell you guys things of how I feel because I donapost really feel anything yet.Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@mirrorRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON FoodViral" data-immediate"data-immediate"Serve the food you really want to eat by signing up for our tips and recipes and never be bored by your cooking againSign UpInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news weird-news woman-jokes-richmond-sausage-lips-"TikToker cracks up at her sausage lips after getting fillerByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Apr |comments A woman has been able to poke fun at herself by sharing a candid insight into the way she looked after she became obsessed with having lip fillers. The woman, named Chelsa, posted a video on TikTok in which she said her lips were once so full of filler that her top lip split in the middle - and she joked she had ended up looking like she had Richmond sausages for lips.Chelsaaposs clip included a picture of herself after her lips had split, and while itaposs unclear when the photo was taken, she explained in the comments that things had gotten out of hand over the course of a few years. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The woman captioned the video: Richmond sausage lips.And in text included in the clip, which was posted under the username @xxchelsaxx, she added: When my lips were so full of filler they split and looked like a bum hole.”Chelsa then offered more insight into her lip disaster in the comments of the video, when she admitted the split was the result of having ml of fillers injected, when most people only have around ml in their lips at a time. However, the woman also stated she got to that stage after slowly increasing the amount of filler she had injected each time, as she told one commenter: It was a gradual build-up over about   years. And while Chelsa can poke fun at her lips now that she limits her injections, itaposs important to understand the risks of going to the extremes with filler, such as migration, which occurs when parts of the body are overfilled. You should always keep track of the amount of filler that will be put into your lips, as it can be easy to get carried away and lose sight of how big your lips might be getting. If youaposve ever had filler before, you should always let your practitioner knowyou already have some filler in your lips before you have more injected - as this will help them assess how much they should be giving you.Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TikTokViralUmm what Beauty trends" data-immediate"data-immediate" for the Real Beauty newsletter and join our community of real people who test products in the real world - all for free!Sign UpInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman slammed out order expecting
story: Woman slammed as out of order for expecting sister-in-law to do school run every dayA woman has claimed her pregnant sister-in-law expects her to do the school run everyday while she is on maternity leave, as she doesnt want to do it with a newbornShes been asked to do the school run every dayImage: Getty ImagesByBrogan-Leigh HurstShowbiz Reporter:,  Apr |commentsWhen it comes to having a baby, many people will often volunteer to help out their nearest and dearest after the birth. But it seems sometimes these kind gestures can get taken for granted and too much can be asked of you, as one woman recently claims to have found out.Mumsnet users have slammed an anonymous pregnant woman for being aposout of orderapos as she asked her sister-in-law to do the daily school run for her, throughout the duration of her maternity leave. Taking to the parenting forum, an upset user shared her dilemma with others, explaining that her sister-in-law was left aposannoyedapos at her when she politely said she wonapost take and collect her daughter from school every day when her maternity leave begins.The woman revealed that her son and her niece will start school in September and are going to be in the same class. She told users that her sister-in-law is currently expecting her second child, and is due to give birth the same month that her daughter starts school.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.I said, aposNo - Iaposve got my own and children and said sheaposll be off anywayapos.She got all annoyed with me and asked how sheaposs meant to do school pick up when the baby is sleeping orsheaposs had a bad night.The woman added that her sister-in-law aposshoutedapos at her as she would have to juggle getting up aposat the crack of dawnapos to take her daughter to school, with looking after a newborn. Asking othersshe is being unreasonable, she said: Iaposm not missing something am I  This is totally out of order - millions of mums including myself have done school pick up and drop off with newborns. Iaposm a firm believer ofyou choose to have children you look after them yourself. I already have my niece after nursery until my brother and SIL finish work, I donapost want to do it when sheaposs at home I want the time sheaposs on mat leave to look after my own children. Sorry for the ramble. In the comments section, people slammed her sister-in-law for being so aposout of orderapos for expecting the woman to go out of her way for months. One said: Wellshe hadnapost been so rude Iaposd say you could offer to do it for the first few weeks and then share it after that. But she should not have demanded and she should not have had a temper tantrum when you said no. Sheaposs burnt her bridges here a bit. Another penned: What a joke! Iaposm also due in Sept and am worried about this but itaposs the reason Iaposm going to get help with the baby at first. If I asked my SIL this she wouldnapost say yes to every day. A third added: No way would I do them simply because she is having another baby. If she was working and struggling to sort it then yes I would help. And a fourth shared: She is being so rude I wouldnapost put myself out for her I would say she needs to make other arrangements for after nursery. Others suggested she offers to split the school run and offer to do the first two weeks after her brother s to work, as they say, it will be the aposhardestapos.Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@mirrorRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON School runBabies" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: meghan markle harry invictus games
story: Exclusive: Meghan Markle and Harry WILL be at Invictus Games on st trip since quitting royalsEXCLUSIVE: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry will travel to Holland next week to attend the launch of the Invictus Games. It will be her first trip outside the US since the couple quit the royal familyMeghan Markle and Prince Harry at the Invictus Games in  Image: XByRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsMeghan Markle will travel with Prince Harry to the Invictus Games in Holland next week, on her first trip outside of the US since the couple quit the royal family. The Mirror can reveal Harry and Meghan will be followed by a Netflix documentary crew throughout the Games, which start next Saturday.The couple’s decision to attend the event in The Hague has been blasted by palace insiders after Harry claimed it was “too dangerous” to travel to the UK.He is locked in a legal battle with the UK government over a decision to downgrade his security, and did not show up at a memorial service for his grandfather, Prince Philip, last week. Ken Wharfe, an ex-Met officer who once protected Harry, said: “I’m baffled about why Harry thinks he would be safer in the Netherlands than the UK. “He would have travelled to his grandfather’s memorial service with his brother or father and received protection from the Met. It’s not like he would have been turning up at Westminster Abbey on a bike. “It is more of a risk to go to Holland to support a charity with a military link than coming to London last week.” A spokesman for Harry and Meghan reportedly said: “We take measures based on the security threat level.”  Since ditching their royal roles to seek “financial independence”, Meghan, , and Harry, , have signed deals with Netflix and Spoty worth more than £million. The couple, who now live in Calornia with children Archie, two, and -month-old Lilibet, are expected to arrive in Holland on Friday. Harry’s father Prince Charles is understood to have offered an olive branch to smooth relations, offering the Duke of Sussex and his family the opportunity to stay with him and we Camilla at Highgrove. But sources close to Charles suggest the invitation “remains unanswered”.  Meghan may join Harry on stage at the Games opening ceremony, insiders promising “a big surprise to launch the event”. A source said: “Meghan is excited to travel with Harry for the event, which is certainly close to his heart.” The couple’s Archewell Productions last April announced its first major docu-series for Netflix would be titled Heart of Invictus, and follow athletes and organisers from across the world on the road to the Games. title: worlds saddest zoo home blind
story: Inside Worlds saddest zoo home to blind bear locked in cage for  yearsWhen officials encountered the zoo dubbed Salvation Park in Armenia, they found dozens of other animals, including a lioness, in a ramshackle dark barn, thought to be rescued from traffickers and huntersA blind bear has been locked in a tiny cage for  years Image: Roger Allen   SplashNewsByTim FriendCharlie Duffield:,  Apr |comments A blind bear has been locked in a cage for  years, and miserable monkeys shrouded in darkness, at the worldaposs saddest zoo .Animal welfare groups are attempting to get the centre - nicknamed Salvation Park - closed down. When officials encountered the zoo in Armenia, they found dozens of other animals, including a lioness and monkeys, in a ramshackle dark barn.Itaposs thought the owner rescued animals from traffickers and hunters, yet one UK charity toldThe Sunthat conditions were shocking and among the worst we’ve seen.Now the Armenian government is being pressurised to shut down the park entirely.  One especially tragic situation saw a blind bear, called Nelson, housed in a dirty cage, with no exercise room for three decades, with rotting teeth and poor eyesight, which could be salvaged with surgery. Campaigners also revealed that a -year-old lioness called Sara, had been trapped in a space equivalent to a garden shed for seven years. Thereaposs also a group of monkeys, captive in a rotting barn with no daylight, and an eagle who is unable to stretch its wings in a small cage. An Armenian goat constantly charges the bars of its ramshackle pen. An animal welfare bill, which would see the zoo closed down, is currently being debated. The UK-based International Animal Rescuehas been trying to save Nelson the bear, but the owner Armen Tadevosyan, , refuses to hand him over.  He claims his animals are well looked after at the zoo in Armavir, which is a small town  miles west of Armenia’s capital, Yerevan. IAR president, Alan Knight OBE, said: The conditions these poor animals are living in are nothing short of hell on earth. The cages are small, filthy and dilapidated to say the least, and the animals have no choice but to stand in the squalor with nothing to break their boredom and frustration.  The idea that members of the public would choose to pay money to see these captive animals suffering behind bars is just laughable. We’ve been trying to rescue the bear, who we called Nelson, for months now with no success, but clearly all the animals in so-called Salvation Park are in urgent need of proper care and attention. As an animal welfare organisation, we are ready and willing to help ensure they get it. IAR has a bear rescue centre in Armenia and has so far saved  animals.  Alan Knight added: It’s a stain on the international reputation of Armenia that it allows sentient creatures to suffer such cruelty and neglect. I urge the government to step in right away and force the closure of the park so that the animals can be given proper food and care for the first time in years. There is no excuse for such cruelty and neglect and I know there will be a public outcry when people read about it.Hopefully public pressure will persuade the government to close the park and start the animals on the road to a better, happierle.That is the only humane and compassionate course of action. title: uk australia trade worries dismissed as fanciful
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. title: food chain worry sparks summit call
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: council withdraws plans to revamp inverurie town hall after hundreds object to desecration of historic building
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: hilton garden inn approved
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
