title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: face coverings to remain legal requirement until april 18
story: coronavirusFace coverings to remain legal requirement until April March ,  at : pmDue to the #very high level of infection# from COVID- and the resultant pressures on the NHS, the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, has announced that the legal requirement to wear a face covering indoors will remain until Monday, April .In setting out the context for this decision, Ms Sturgeon referred to the most recent Office of National Statistics COVID infection survey which found that one in  people in Scotland had the virus – the highest level of infection that has been recorded so far in these surveys.“The volume of people in hospital with COVID is causing very signicant pressure for a health service that has been dealing with the pandemic for more than two years now,# she said. #That means we cannot be complacent.”Despite the high rates of infection, the First Minister found some cause for optimism from the daily data, suggesting that the peak of the current wave has been reached and that the infection rate is perhaps stabilising.Nevertheless, the legal requirement to wear a face covering will remain for places of worship or for events like weddings or funerals until Monday, April .As of Monday, April , it will become guidance, rather than a requirement, to wear face coverings on public transport and in shops and other indoor spaces.Ms Sturgeon said: “This phased approach strikes, I think, a sensible balance between our desire to remove this one remaining legal measure and the common sense need for continued caution, not least for the sake of the NHS while this wave of infection does subside.”In addition, for the period until Easter, everyone will continue to be asked to take to lateral flow tests twice a week, and to take a daily test for seven daysyou are a close contact of someone who has tested positive. People are also being advised to take a test prior to visiting someone who is vulnerable.If you develop symptoms, you should continue to get a PCR test.On vaccination, the First Minister said: “The advice to everyone, of course, remains as important as ever – please do take the opportunity to get vaccinated as soon as you are able and make sure you get all doses of vaccine that you are eligible for. This remains the most important thing any of us can do to protect ourselves and others.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: hoy head returns while the graemsay goes on refit
story: newsHoy Head s while the Graemsay goes on refitApril ,  at : pmIt#s a case of one in, one out, for the south isles ferries.The Hoy Head has ed from refit and has resumed sailing the Houton, Flotta, Lyness route, which had been covered by the Thorsvoe.While the Graemsay has gone for refit and the Stromness, Graemsay, Moaness route is being covered by The Nordic Sea.A spokeswoman for the council said: #It is hoped that the Graemsay will be back in service the last week in April.#However nothing is straight forward, due to prevailing weather and predicted tidal heights, on Wednesday April , the vessel has had to cancel all scheduled arrivals and departures from Moaness, while all sailings to Graemsay are under review.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: new cathedral vestibule complete
story: The transformation of St Magnus Cathedral#s west door vestibule is now complete, giving access through the main door for the first time in two years.Moderator of the Church of Scotland, Lord Jim Wallace, will be performing a sermon in the Cathedral on Palm Sunday, April , and has been asked to give a short dedication, which will be followed by a blessing from Cathedral Minister, Reverend Fraser Macnaughton.Custodian and visitor services officer, Fran Hollinrake, had the privilege of opening the main door on Tuesday morning.“I was so delighted to be given the honour of unlocking the main entrance doors after two years’ closure due to COVID and the restoration works,# she said.#The new vestibule has been signed off and means it is available for use so that everyone can enjoy this, not only practical new entryway, but also its magnicence.”The restoration and the new vestibule have been made possible with funding from the Society of the Friends of St Magnus, and the work was carried out by local firm Casey Construction Ltd, under the watchful eye of the Cathedral’s Historic Buildings Conservator, Meredith Macbeth.Elaine Grieve, chairwoman of the Society of the Friends of St Magnus Cathedral said: “The Cathedral is so precious that it is hard to contemplate making any changes for fear they won’t do the building justice.#However, in this case, what an absolutely wonderful transformation the vestibule has made to the entrance of the building. The craftmanship is outstanding and we now have an addition which befits this treasured building loved by so many near and far.”The Cathedral is managed by Orkney Islands Council on behalf of the people of Orkney.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: oic election full candidate list revealed
story: Campaign season is now officially under way for the Orkney Islands Council election, after the full list of candidates was declared this Wednesday evening.Voters across Orkney are set to head to the polls on May , to elect the  councillors who will represent them for the next five years.Membership within the OIC chamber is broken up into six electoral wards. These wards, and their candidates are as follows:East Mainland, Burray and South Ronaldsay Kirkwall East Kirkwall West and Orphir North Isles Stromness and South Isles West Mainland Anyone aged  or over that day, resident in Orkney and registered to vote, will be able to vote. Letters have recently been sent to all properties, listing electors who are currently registered to vote andthey have a postal vote in place.Anyone not included on that letter can register to vote between now and Monday, April . Anyone registered to vote but not listed as a postal voter can apply to vote by post which must be ed by pm on Tuesday, April , or sooner.For full coverage of the election as we head towards polling day, pick up The Orcadian, available in shops and online from Wednesday each week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orcadian composer receives royal commission
story: An Orkney-born composer is royally chuffed to have been selected to help mark HM Queen#s Platinum Jubilee.Erland Cooper, who originally hails from Stromness, has been commissioned to create an original piece of music to soundtrack the floral transformation of The Tower of London.Entitled Superbloom, the forthcoming installation will celebrate  years of Queen Elizabeth II#s reign.The project is named after a rare and incredible natural phenomenon, where whole landscapes are miraculously transformed into sheets of vibrant flowers.A “superbloom” occurs only once every few decades, when favourable weather patterns coincide and activate dormant seeds. The forthcoming #designed# Superbloom event will celebrate nature by turning one of London’s most built-up areas into a blossoming, living flower field.Erlandhas been chosen to produce a gentle accompanying ambient soundscape for this urban garden, which will be played continuously through speakers, softening the noise of the city.He explained: #Music For Growing Flowers aims to enhance the Superbloom’s emotional impact by rebalancing the dominant city noises and intertwining specic audio frequencies to uncover harmony in the most bustling environments.Since music itself is nothing more than vibrations, perhaps it will help us enter more deeply into this subtle appreciation of place, curiosity and calm.”For his most recent album, the composer ed to his Orkney roots, actually planting the only existing Carves the Runes Then Be Content With Silence at a hidden location in the county.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: orkney to bloom in new series of beechgrove
story: newsOrkney to bloom in new series of BeechgroveApril ,  at : amThe latest series of Scotland’s premier gardening programme Beechgrovewill follow the toil and soil of an Orkney garden. vw, px"  The series introduced the a new strand ‘Beechgrowers’ last year, which followed the sprouts and doubts of six gardeners across Scotland.This year the Beechgrowers are back, with six new hopeful horticulturalists, including Orkney based Sanne de Koeijer.Sanne, who is described as #a student, studying  Culture and Heritage with Gaelic studies. She grew up gardening with her grandparents in the Netherlands, and likes the idea of growing to feed yourself.#She has a  x  plot at a local community garden and the series will follow her green fingered venture.Beechgrove Executive producer Gwyneth Hardy said: “Our Beechgrowers – including Sanne #  are all raring to go this year to share their gardening experiences, tips and occasional disasters.“There is a big emphasis among this year’s Beechgrowers on growing your own food, but they all promise to have a wealth of gardening stories to share across the board.”Viewers will be introduced to Sanne in episode two which is due to be aired on April .The new series of Beechgrove will air on Thursday’s at .pm BBC Scotland and will be repeated on Friday at . on BBC , the first episode will go out ion April .The programme will also be available on the BBC iPlayer.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: parish cup draw made
story: The draw for The Orcadian Parish Cup has been made — with a potential heavyweight clash between Holm and Stromness in the quarter finals.Fteen teams were in the hat this morning as the draw for the first round was made live on BBC Radio Orkney, before the draw for the quarter final was made off-air.This year saw two teams re-enter the cup after period of absences in Harray and Stronsay, and as usual, there was no shortage of intrigue and suspense as teams and communities discovered what the famed Radio Orkney Quality Street tin had in store for them.The full draw for the first round is:Deerness v StromnessHolm v StennessBirsay v StronsayRendall v SandayHarray v St AndrewsFirth v St OlaSandwick v South RonaldsayWestray — byeThe first-leg first-round ties will be played over the weekend of May  and .The full draw for the quarter final is:Holm Stenness v Deerness StromnessRendall Sanday v Firth St OlaWestray v Harray St AndrewsSandwick South Ronaldsay v Birsay Stronsay.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: perfect of para sports held at picky
story: newsPerfect day of para-sports held at PickyMarch ,  at : pmOrkney held it’s first Para-sports festival to the delight ofvw, px"   participants.The festival, which had one athlete claim “This is the best day of my le,” was open to those aged  to  and have a physical, visual or hearing impairment.The day allowed people a chance to try a iety of exciting sports from badminton, athletics and swimming to kayaking, rugby and boccia # a sport similar to bowling, designed for athletes with support needs.The event, held on March , was supported by Scottish Disability Sport, with a number of sport specic specialists delivering activities, including Orkney’s Active Schools team, the Council’s Community Sport Hub Officer, local sporting clubs, and Orkney’s new charity, Inclusive Orkney.Joanne Cairns the council#s community sports officer added: “One parent has already written into us to thank us for a ‘superb day’ and for all the work ourselves and others are doing ‘to give those less able a chance to try new things and celebrate their dferences instead of seeing them as a barrier. It was a very special day indeed!’. Feedback like that just puts a smile on your face!”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Ralf Rangnick made clear the extent of his future consultancy role at Manchester United would depend on the club’s new manager.The interim boss would not be drawn on reports that Ajax boss Erik Ten Hag had been lined up as the next permanent appointment at Old Trafford, saying his focus was purely on Saturday’s trip to relegation-battling Everton.Rangnick was also asked about his own future at the end of a week in which the Austrian Football Association denied having spoken to the -year-old about their vacant manager’s position, and said he would discuss his two-year consultancy contract at the end of the season.But askedhe would be offering thorough insight to the next manager, Rangnick said: “I have already done this, not to any managers, but inside the club.“I have told them how I see the current squad and what needs to happen in my opinion. The rest I cannot answer now because it depends on the new manager. If he is interested and willing to speak about that and interested in my opinion, I will need to wait and see what happens.”And asked what would be the most important advice he could offer a new manager, Rangnick added: “If the new manager has been announced, thenhe wants to get my advice then I am more than happy to speak to the new manager about that.Three goals and three points in our last #PL visit to Goodison Park 💪🔴#MUFC | #EVEMUN pic cfABjCrdm— Manchester UnitedApril , “But right now it will be something in private and internally, that we need to discuss.”United face a busy summer, not only with the arrival of a new boss, but also in rebuilding a squad which is set to lose six out-of-contract players – Paul Pogba, Jesse Lingard, Edinson Cavani, Juan Mata, Tahith Chong and Lee Grant – while many others on the fringes face uncertain futures.When Rangnick was hired, much was made of his role in creating the influential gergenpress amid hopes he could install a coherent philosophy at a club which has a bloated squad made up of players signed by five dferent managers.But though he said he had spoken to the board “and they know what I think needs to happen in the summer”, Rangnick was clear the final decisions on several iniduals would rest with his successor. vw,vw,px, px"Donny Van De Beek is on loan at Everton Answering a question on whether Donny Van De Beek, on loan at Everton but unable to face his parent club this weekend, had a future at Old Trafford, Rangnick said: “I will not be the manager next season.“It also depends on how you want to play. Do you want to play more possession based or counter pressing, pressing kind of football  It depends on that and what other kind of players are coming.“The squad needs to be rebuilt in the summer, that is clear.“But again, those are questions that it doesn’t make sense to speak about right now.”Luke Shaw is one of four players ruled out of Saturday’s lunchtime fixture – Raphael Varane, Scott McTominay and Edinson Cavani are also missing – with Rangnick revealing the England left-back needs an operation to remove metal screws from his leg dating to his double leg-break in .🚨 Four first-team Reds have been ruled out of Saturdays #PL encounter.#MUFC | #EVEMUN— Manchester UnitedApril , “To me it came quite unexpectedly to be honest and the same is true of our medical department,” Rangnick said.“He told me in the international break when he was with the England squad that he had some problems there and he played against Leicester and five minutes before half-time he had an issue and had to be treated on the pitch.“At half-time the doctor came to see me and said he could not continue and since then we have been discussing what is best and they decided to have the two bolts removed.”

title: lace to compete at crufts for fifth time
story: A Sandwick woman and her seven-year-old dog will compete at Crufts in a Scottish team this week # for the fth time together.Sally Sanford and Lace, her Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever, will take part in the rally event on Thursday at the NEC in Birmingham.The pair are part of a Scotland team who will face Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regional teams in the inter-regional rally competition.The rally course sees dog and handler work as a pair to navigate a course of between  and  dferent exercises.Ms Sanford said the competition was always #a step-up#.#You#re asking the dogs to do stuff that isn#t that complicated for them, but it#s the handlers who need to be able to multi-task, to concentrate in the moment and navigate their way around the course.#You need your head in the game.#But she said that was one of Lace#s strengths, and said he had finished second in his event previously.The pair are hoping for another strong showing, but with Crufts taking place for the first time since March , she said there were some uncertainties.#None of us know how busy Crufts is going to be this year,# she said.#I would be lyingI said there wasn#t a degree of trepidation.#She said that she was excited for theof the #enormous# event, though, and hopes Lace will be able to inspire Scotland to better their previous best performance of third...Pet pooches are being given the chance to test their agility and obedience without even having to leave their own gardens – proving that lockdownSandwick resident Sally Sanford will be appearing at the Crufts dog show this week as part of the Scottish rally team with her Nova ScotiaA dog lover from Bigton says that making the final in the Kennel Club’s Eukanuba Friends for Le competition at Crufts  would mean the#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: orchestras summer tour offers creative opportunities for musical bairns
story: The Scottish Chamber Orchestrarsquos revived summer tour will visit Shetland to deliver creative opportunities for youngsters and a child-friendly performance.After a two year break the SCO is ing with a tour of  Scottish towns and cities ndash including Lerwick and Brae.Next up, the SCO #Vibe will be held at the Anderson High School in Lerwick, from th-th June, offering free creative music-making opportunities.ldquoWe work without written notation to develop composition, improvisation and performance skills, build confidence, and have fun making music, the SCO said.The tour is aimed to fulfil the SCOrsquos commitment to ldquoenrich the lives of as many people as possible by showcasing world-class music to audiences who might otherwise not experience it.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming audiences to share in the joy of live music-making, both in the concert hall and beyond...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. title: isles lass to get six return flights after nomination from fiance
story: Lerwick lass Zoe Buchanan will fly home to visit her family in Shetland several times this year after being selected as a winner of a Loganair competition.The -year-old youth worker, who now lives in Forest of Dean in Gloucestershire, was nominated in Loganair#s Diamond Ticket competition by her fiancé Lucy Young.She nominated Ms Buchanan for always thinking of others before herself # despite recently discovering she is in kidney failure.Loganair launched the competition to celebrate its th anniversary, offering a deserving person  free flights across its network.Ms Buchanan was one of two runners-up, who will enjoy six freeflights to Shetland as she awaits a kidney transplant.Ms Young said of selecting her fiancé: #I nominated Zoe because she is so kind and caring, and has always put others before herself.#Especially now as she awaits a kidney transplant, she continues to work part-time supporting organisations in the local community.#Being able to visit friends and family in her hometown more frequently would mean the world.#And Ms Buchanan said she #couldn#t believe it# when she was told about the prize.Loganair#s chief operating officer Kay Ryan said being able to reconnect Ms Buchanan with her family and friends #encapsulates the essence of the airline#.#We are delighted to be able to gt these flights which can facilitate more treasured family memories. We look forward to being part of her special trips.#..Loganair is to add a fuel surcharge of £. to all new bookings from st March. The airline#s chief executive Jonathan Hinkles said the #huge#Airline Loganair is celebrating its diamond anniversary todayas it looks back on  years of taking to the skies. Formed on st February#Loganair has reported a seven-fold increase in the number of calls to its customer team with many folk needing to rearrange bookings due to Covid-Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: editorial budhmor decision must be
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineJust  weeks’ notice has been given to families to make new arrangements for their loved ones, and while staff have apparently been offered alternative positions, there is considerable anger and upset among workers who have served the home and those who have lived in it with diligence and compassion over many years. adds our voice in support, and in doing so raises further questions about the provision of care for the region’s elderly.Not so very long ago there were residential care homes in just about every district of Skye and Lochalsh # in Staffin, Struan, Dunvegan, Uig, Broadford and Dornie.But changing regulations on facilities and staff were not sufficiently accompanied by support for the owners to make the transition the new rules demanded of them. It is now surely a matter of huge regret for our communities that so many small-scale care providers # despite their good reputation and obvious appeal in rural parts of the country – have been allowed to wither on the vine and disappear. on standards which followed the Covid outbreak in April and May .Budhmor’s owners are not a shadowy offshore conglomerate trying to put profit before care – but CrossReach, the social arm of the Church of Scotland. Despite their benevolent roots, the modern pressures facing the sector, they say, simply make it too dficult to keep their Portree home open.The building needs too much work and they don’t have the money to pay for it.The only option, families were told, is closure – with the suggestion that the  residents could all be accommodated nearby in a refurbished and expanded Home Farm.It is not dficult to understand why families are so aggrieved at this proposal.Things may well have improved at Home Farm since the horrors of Covid, but have all the lessons been learned The blanket national policy of shting patients from hospitals to care homes in the frantic weeks of early  was a huge factor in the devastating Covid death toll that followed.Yet now, with the pandemic still not behind us, families in Skye are being told they should accept the transfer en masse of their elderly relatives to the very home so ravaged by coronavirus when it was proven to be over capacity and understaffed.At Budhmor, they managed to keep the home safe from the worst of Covid-. Relatives of residents will tell you that was no fluke – but down to good standards, diligent management and conscientious staff.There will be some truth in the financial and staffing pressures that CrossReach cite in their reasons for closure. But two years on from the outset of Covid, should the sector not be doing all it can to preserve and build on the success of an institution which proved such a good example during the pandemic, rather than bowing to the bottom line and accepting its loss.There is also the matter of an options appraisal on health and care needs in the north of Skye, currently being prepared by NHS Highland.Closure must at the very least be halted until this review is complete – andthis requires support for CrossReach, our Government should find it.In the longer term what we really need are alternative models to those that are currently governed by economies of scale than on inidual or community needs. An agenda of rationalisation and centralisation has taken hold of far too many of our public services and is ultimately driving decisions like the closure of small care facilities offering a homely, personalised environment in favour of a vast, but possibly distant one many miles from an inidual’s home community.No-where has this been more obvious, or dangerous, than in the west Highland health and care sector.We should start the fightback by backing Budhmor care home, and keeping it open.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220406newschinese named northern ireland s most popular takeaway
story: The decision-making process of ordering a takeaway often ides opinion, with debates sparking almost every day as households fail to come to an agreement on which delicious treat they should indulge in. But is your preferred cuisine dependent on where you live  Wanting to settle the age-old debate, Just-Eat have conducted a sentiment analysis of over  million restaurant reviews across the UK. Each gastronomy was awarded a popularity score out of  based on the positive sentiments surrounding each food genre, ultimately uncovering the most popular cuisine across the UK. Just-Eat can reveal that Chinese cuisine is the most popular across Northern Ireland. The classic dishes that rank as the country’s favourites include sweet and sourand chow mein . Close in popularity is Japanese cuisine, which gains second place with its score of .. Here, tofu dishesare slightly more popular than sushi . Italian is once again a popular choice, and for Northern Ireland it’s the peoples’ third favourite cuisine, scoring . out of . The highest rated Italian dish is ravioli , closely followed by lasagnaand macaroni and cheese . Attaining a positive rank in the top five for the first time, British fare is Northern Ireland’s fourth favourite cuisine, claiming . popularity points. Black pudding is the number one British dish in Northern Ireland, scoring an impressive . out of . The Yorkshire pudding is the second favouriteand the classic BLT sandwich is the third most popular choicein Northern Ireland. Rounding off Northern Ireland’s top five favourite cuisines is Indian with a popularity rating of . out of . Creamy butter chicken is the first choice dish , with kormaand chicken tikkaclose in rankings.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220407newsthe people you are visiting may be particularly vulnerable
story: The public has been urged to keep wearing face coverings when visiting hospitals, care homes and other health and care settings. The appeal from the Chief Medical Officer comes with reports of a decline in wearing of face coverings by visitors. Professor Sir Michael McBride said: “The COVID- Omicron iant is extremely infectious and, despite best efforts, can spread quickly in health and social care settings. “Please remember to wear a face covering when you are visiting. The people you are coming to see may be particularly vulnerable to the virus - as may other patients or residents. “Also, do not visityou have symptoms of respiratory infection.” The Chief Medical Officer added: “Wearing a face covering remains an important way to protect others, as well as yourself. Public health advice continues to encourage their use in everyday le. That also includes on public transport and in any indoor busy setting - especiallythey are not well ventilated.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220407newstranslink bus drivers to go on strike later this month
story: Unite has confirmed initial dates for strike action on Ulsterbus andbus services. These will be taken in conjunction with GMB who also represents bus workers at Translink. The strike action planned will be a week, starting April  and concluding on May , as well as a single day on Friday, May . The strike comes after members of the union overwhelmingly voted for industrial action after rejecting the latest Translink management pay offer. Unite general secretary Sharon Graham expressed her support for the striking bus workers. She said, “These bus workers are frontline workers – they deserve respect and a pay increase. Translink needs to grasp that there’s a cost of living crisis destroying the value of wages andwith a more acceptable offer. “Unite’s members have my full support and that of their union in taking this strike action for fairer pay.” Unite deputy Regional Secretary Davy Thompson is lead officer for Translink, Northern Ireland’s bus and rail public transport provider. He added:“Unite represents the overwhelming majority of bus workers, and this strike action taken in conjunction with GMB which also represents bus workers will shut down all bus services. “Bus workers deserve a pay increase. The ball is in the court of Translink management. They can to avoid this unnecessary and highly disruptive strike – they need to address our members’ legitimate pay expectations.” Meanwhile, Peter Macklin, GMB Organiser, said:Every worker deserves fair pay. With rampant inflation, this real terms cut is a slap in the face and will leave many struggling to cover their bills. “Translinkfails to recognise what workers went through during the pandemic. “They kept transport running so other essential workers could get to and from workplaces to perform vital roles. “Our members were proud to carry out their duty in delivering the service, potentially putting themselves and their families at risk. When we clapped every Thursday night, we said the essential workers would not be forgotten or left behind. But during this cost of living crisis, Translink is forgetting their own workers. “The dispute, which affects bus drivers, cleaners and shunters will close the entire bus network within Northern Ireland. It will be a complete shutdown.” A Translink spokesperson said they were disappointed that the unions hadvoted to take industrial action. “Following extensive negotiations, including with the Labour Relations Agency, we made a pay offer of % plus an enhanced package of conditions that included a % increase in weekend and overtime rates along with  extra days holiday, they said. “We believe this was a fair and reasonable offer and have at all times been open to discussions. We remain committed to working with the unions to avert this action. “We would welcome the opportunity to engage with unions to cover school duties, so that the wellbeing of schoolchildren can remain a priority. “All train services will continue to operate as normal. “We will communicate relevant passenger information through the media, on our website www.translink, through social media, in stations and on buses and trains. “Translink apologises for any inconvenience this may cause”.

title: ballycastle is northern irelands best place to live in 2022 proud locals are in full agreement as co antrim town edges out derry and
story: Seafront: Ballycastle has been named Northern Ireland#s best place to live in the annual Sunday Times list.The mile-long beach at Ballycastle was described as beautulMarie Fox with baby EvaFinn DelaneyClaire Byrne FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSeafront: Ballycastle has been named Northern Ireland#s best place to live in the annual Sunday Times list.Allan PrestonTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailFor the people of Ballycastle, it seems an obvious choice their home town has been picked as the best place to live in Northern Ireland.As they pass by its picturesque harbour, families and business owners in the Co Antrim town talk fondly of the epic coastal views on their doorstep.Rathlin Island is a short ferry trip away and Scotland is also visible on a clear day.Although a small seaside town, Ballycastle boasts a thriving Main Street with multiple cafes, greengrocers and fish and chip shops.Picked as part of the annual Sunday Times Best Places to Live, Ballycastle was chosen ahead of Londonderry and Helen’s Bay.Read MoreGarrett Hargan:OpinionDerry one of best places to live in Northern Ireland: A rich history, friendly people, and proud music and sporting traditions make city a fantastic place to liveDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read More‘There’s no place like home’: Derry Girls writer Lisa McGee reacts to city being named among top places to live in NIRead MoreBest places to live in the UK revealed They said of Ballycastle: “This unspoilt fishing village is a real coastal town rather than a tourist honeypot, with a strong independent streak and a welcoming atmosphere.“There’s a vibrant food scene, with everything from old-fashioned fish and chips at Morton’s by the harbour to tasty sourdough at Ursa Minor bakery.“The mile-long beach and beautul surroundings make it a blissful base for families.”With an average house price of £,, Ballycastle has experienced growth of % since .Enjoying time at the play park with two of her children, lelong resident Marie Foxagreed it was an ideal spot for families.“It’s definitely good for young ones. Great schools and it’s brilliant for walks on the beach,” she said.“It does get a lot busier here in the summer as well whenever we get the markets.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseMarie Fox with baby Eva FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMarie Fox with baby EvaPrimary school teacher Claire Byrne said: “We go for a walk every single day and it’s lovely just to get out.“My children have grown up here and went to secondary school and they have loved it.” Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseClaire Byrne FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueClaire ByrneAt family-run Shorebird Coffee Hut, James Delaneyand son Finnagreed their home town was a worthy winner.“It’s not a big surprise, really. I have five kids and they all play sports and last night we had a party for an aunt out in one of the local restaurants,” said James.“In Portrush you will get a lot more things like arcades, but people like that Ballycastle is unspoiled in that way.”He said one downside was the lack of a leisure centre with a swimming pool, meaning locals had to travel to Ballymoney or Coleraine.Finn added: “I do think it is a nice place to live, it’s a good mix of tourists and local people. So you know all the faces and there’s plenty of places to walk.“Looking out the window you can see Scotland on a clear day.” Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseFinn Delaney FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFinn DelaneyAskedhe ever feels cut off from areas like Belfast, he said: “To be honest, there’s plenty of stuff to do here.“You get lots of people from surrounding towns coming down here, even though it’s not a massive community, people come down for all the bars and nightclubs.”Dympna McNallylives in London still visits Ballycastle, where her parents grew up, once a month.“I can only speak personally, but I do think it’s quite friendly. I like the fact it’s not too busy, the scenery is beautul, the shops are good. What more could you ask for ” she said.“A downside is that it’s not very well connected with transport links. It’s a shame the train doesn’t come here anymore.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDympna McNally from London visits Ballycastle every month. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDympna McNally from London visits Ballycastle every month.Ulster Unionist councillor Joan Baird spent her school years in the town. She said it became a refuge for her during the Troubles when she visited her parents at the weekend.“The community here, by and large, has got on very well together over the years and still does,” she said.“This is going to be demonstrated now when we get our shared campus between the senior schools in the town.“All of that adds up to a very good community. People are very friendly and it is a lovely place to live, with the beautul environment we have with the Glens of Antrim.“Of course, you have the sea and Rathlin Island so close by.“It’s a fabulous place to live, but it’s very important that we keep it that way.“It’s not just going to always happen. You have to strive to make sure that ethos of community spirit and togetherness survives into the future.”Sinn Fein councillor Cara McShane said it was “fantastic news” for Ballycastle.“It’s a privilege to live and work here,” she said.“We are never complacent about this part of the world — there’s stunning views of Rathlin Island, Mull of Kintyre, Fair Head clf, which is nestled in the shadow of Knockglade Mountain.”She added a major selling point was a strong, independent retail offering, as well as a high number of producers in the local artisan food market.While frustrated at times that local government spending can be “Coleraine and Portrush-centric”, she is hopeful of plans currently out for consultation for a new greenway linking Ballymoney and Ballycastle.“That will offer people coming from places like Belfast the chance to get the train as far as Ballymoney, and of course you could then cycle, walk or run to Ballycastle,” she said.“That is exciting. We know we live in a unique area.“But we’re always progressive and thinking of other ways to let other people come to Ballycastle.”Related topicsUlster Unionist PartySinn FéinMore On Ulster Unionist Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumDerry one of best places to live in Northern Ireland: A rich history, friendly people, and proud music and sporting traditions make city a fantastic place to liveGarrett HarganExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDerry City Walls FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDerry City WallsApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailDerry has rightly been recognised as one of the best places to live in Northern Ireland given the city’s welcoming atmosphere and history.The Sunday Times took account of a wide range of factors — from schools, transport and broadband to culture, green spaces and the health of the high street.The Best Places to Live list celebrates improving towns, villages or city centres, attractive, well-designed homes and locations bursting with community spirit.What makes Derry a great place to live is its rich history and people who are both warm and friendly with a sense of comradery.That is not conjecture or bias from a local, but is borne out in polls where the city sits at the top for being the most generous in the UK for donations on pages such as GoFundMe.The city is believed to have been founded by Saint Columba in AD . That means there is much for visitors to explore, from ancient to modern history.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreBallycastle is Northern Ireland’s best place to live in : Proud locals are in full agreement as Co Antrim town edges out Derry and Helen’s Bay‘There’s no place like home’: Derry Girls writer Lisa McGee reacts to city being named among top places to live in NIYou have the completely intact -year-old Derry Walls which is a real selling point for tourists.Other historic landmarks include the Guildhall — where it now stands was once the middle of the River Foyle where ships moored. It was mostly destroyed by fire in  and after extensive rebuilding was opened in .Because it is relatively small in size, Derry is an easy place to navigate for visitors.A key piece of infrastructure built in recent times was the Peace Bridge.Nowadays it is hard to imagine the city without it, and it’s an area of recreation popular with walkers and joggers.That area is arguably the best feature of the city, expanding the city centre, linking to Ebrington, St Columb’s Park and the renovated railway station.The Peace Bridge connects the Cityside and Waterside it was a masterstroke both in practical terms and as an act of symbolism by reconnecting the largely Catholic Cityside to the traditionally unionist Waterside. Derry is also a city of culture — made official in  — with musicians, poets, painters and actors famous the world over.Danny Boy is one of the most famous songs in the world, and has been covered by Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and Eva Cassidy. Phil Coulter, The Undertones, Dana, Cara Dillon, Johnny McDaid of Snow Patrol fame, Red Organ Serpent Sound, Fighting with Wire, SOAK and Wood Burning Savages show the range of musicians Derry has produced.It is also a city with proud sporting traditions in GAA and football and has produced Olympic medallists and world champions who first learned their trade on Derry’s pitches, roads and rivers.Nowhere does a festival like Derry, but there should be more added to the calendar.You have Glasgowbury in Draperstown, the City of Derry Jazz and Big Band Festival, the legendary Halloween festival and, in recent times, the Foyle Maritime Festival, which have all proven popular.When considering Derry, you also have to factor in the location. A short drive across the border and you’re in some of the world’s nicest beaches including Dunree and Tullagh Bay.To Derry’s advantage in the Sunday Times survey was an average house price of £,.“Reaping the rewards of years of investment and with a fine cultural reputation, this much-improved city stands out as somewhere cool, credible and cheap, with a bright future,” The Sunday Times states.But most people in the city would disagree with that statement, as multiple-deprivation measures, unemployment rates and analysis of investment show the second city has not received a great deal of inward investment.For example, since Invest NI was formed in  until   it has assisted , new jobs in Belfast whereas Foyle got , and East Londonderry ,.In that time it invested £.bn in Belfast and £.bn between Foyle and East Londonderry.Most ReadBallycastle is Northern Ireland’s best place to live in : Proud locals are in full agreement as Co Antrim town edges out Derry and Helen’s BayMan title: new belfast transport hub to be named belfast grand central station
story: Artist impression of the new Belfast Transport Hub which will be situated on Translink property near the current Europa Buscentre and Great Victoria Street Stations. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueArtist impression of the new Belfast Transport Hub which will be situated on Translink property near the current Europa Buscentre and Great Victoria Street Stations.Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast’s new transport hub will be officially named Belfast Grand Central Station, Translink has confirmed.Work on the south Belfast station began in February and is expected to open by . The major infrastructural scheme led by Northern Ireland’s public transport provider stretches across , sqft, replacing the existing Europa and Great Victoria Street bus and rail stations. When completed, it will become the largest integrated transport hub on the island of Ireland.The hub will provide  bus stands, eight railway s and an enhanced walking and cycling connectivity across the city.When the £m project was announced in , Translink said the project would create  new jobs.Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon, who visited the project’s building site earlier this year, described it as “exciting” and said it will be a “game changer” for Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “I have been clear that we need to see an increase in the use of public transport and encourage more people to consider active travel options so that we can tackle the climate crisis,” she said.“To achieve that we need to have the right infrastructure in place.”Another project running alongside the Transport Hub at Weavers Cross close to Sandy Row will also regenerate the .m square foot brownfield site in the area.Ms Mallon added: “With an expected annual footfall of over  million, this important NI Executive flagship project will bring a host of benefits to support the economy.“It will improve connectivity for everyone in Northern Ireland and beyond, and will be a key driver of social, economic and environmental wellbeing for the local and wider community.On Thursday, Translink tweeted that the new Grand Central is being “celebrated with community engagement, through an innovative ‘It’s Grand’ Story Board at Europa Bus Centre”. The new station is also only a stone’s throw away from the Hastings-owned Grand Central Hotel, which opened on Bedford Street in .The name itself is full of history, as the city’s first Grand Central Hotel was opened on Royal Avenue in June  by Downpatrick man John Robb.He had originally planned to develop a huge central railway terminus on the site – based on New York#s famous Grand Central Station – but failed to get support from local politicians at the time.It closed its doors in  when the Troubles broke out and was later taken over by the Army in  for use as a base, eventually being demolished in the late s. The site is now home to the Castle Court shopping centre.The train station formerly known as Belfast Central, which is located on Bridge Street in the Laganside area of the city, was renamed Lanyon title: northern ireland weather frosty friday night ahead and scattered saturday showers expected
story: FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFriday night is set to be freezing across Northern Ireland, with temperatures dropping to - °C and frost expected around Mid Ulster and the more southern counties.The Met Office forecasted a cold evening, as Belfast saw sporadic bouts of hail and snow throughout Friday afternoon. Scattered showers will become more confined to northern Ulster counties on Friday night, especially near the north coast, and a light northwesterly wind is to be expected too. Saturday is thought to be cold, mostly dry and bright, but the odd shower has been predicted across NI, with a maximum temperature of  °C and some sunny spells.Sunday is believed to be mainly dry and bright but with clouding over later in the day.Monday and Tuesday are thought to be mostly cloudy with outbreaks of rain.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to title: regeneration plan to be developed for frightening shaftesbury square in belfast
story: Belfast#s Shaftesbury Square. Picture: Google Maps FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBelfast#s Shaftesbury Square. Picture: Google MapsMichael Kenwood, Local Democracy reporterApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast council has vowed to work on a “tactical regeneration” plan for the rundown Shaftesbury Square area in the city centre.The area used to be the crowning glory of Belfast’s so-called “golden mile” – which stretched from Lisburn Road along the fullof Great Victoria Street – but in recent decades has seen steady decline and is noted for its empty premises and dilapidated facades.This week during a meeting of the City Growth and Regeneration Committee at Belfast City Council, elected representatives agreed a proposal from council officers to create a plan for the area to be shared with the relevant Stormont departments, businesses and other stakeholders. The “tactical regeneration” scheme will also look at enhancement of the Castle Street area.It involves quick short term and low cost actions such as transforming dingy former shopfronts, opening up public realm space by taking away street clutter such as bollards, opening up fenced off areas, introducing artworks, parklets and greening.A committee report states: “Whilst certain businesses have sustained a presence in the area and continue to make a positive contribution in terms of well-maintained active frontages, there are a number of vacancies and the wider area is in need of signicant intervention.“It should be noted that there are several development proposals progressing through the planning process in the wider area, and major public sector placemaking and infrastructure projects like Belfast Streets Ahead  and BRT  also have the potential to have a transformative impact.“However, the timescales associated with emerging or committed public and private projects in this area are y, and in some cases uncertain, and there is a growing consensus among local stakeholders that there is a need for shorter term action.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up It adds: “Officers are proposing that a tactical regeneration scheme is worked up for part of this area initially. Whilst the detail needs to be developed, it could include a combination of minor works to building frontages, while also taking advantage of generous footway widths along Great Victoria Street through measures such as removal of street clutter and introduction of soft landscaping and greening opportunities, where possible.“It is proposed that a scheme be developed that focuses on Great Victoria Street, east and west sides, from Bruce St to Donegall Rd, as a priority given the condition of this area.”The council says that the Stormont Department for Communities has indicated that funding may be available in the   financial period,projects can be developed up to a “business case” status.Further funding may come from the South West Quarter Stakeholders Group, a group comprising a mix of private sector business council officers, Translink, NIHE and two Stormont departments.DUP Botanic Councillor Tracy Kelly said: “If you look at Great Victoria Street and the mouth of the city centre, it’s absolutely horrendous. It needs a massive piece of work and investment. So I am so glad to see some thought going into it.“There are a few shops going on to the Donegall Road, just off Shaftesbury Square that recently got funding from the council to give them a bit of a le with shop front work and a bit of paint, and that has made a massive dference already.”She added: “When you think of the golden mile, and what it used to be – it is quite frightening now at night time around there.”Green Councillor Mal O’Hara said: “Parts of the inner fringe around the city core have been ruined by the car dependency of this city and the need to ensure we have traffic flow. Sandy Row, a once vibrant and bustling shopping district, has been ruined to become a cut-through for traffic flow.” He asked for space to be taken away from private cars as part of the regeneration projects.In , a £ million Belfast Transport Hub was approved by the council, involving the creation of a new bus and train centre on the other side of Durham Street to the current Great Victoria Street bus and train stations Those stations will be replaced with a mall.The wider Weaver’s Cross plan involves the regeneration of land to the immediate south of the current train and bus centre, land currently used as parking space on either side of Hope Street and Bruce Street, cutting through Great Victoria Street. A public space is planned beside the new transport hub called “Saltwater Square.”Most ReadBallycastle is Northern Ireland’s best place to live in : Proud locals are in full agreement as Co Antrim town title: alliance assembly candidate connie egan jokes that vandals of her election posters are terrible at art
story: Connie Egan and Andrew Muir had their photographs defaced on election posters throughout parts of Bangor this week. Credit: Connie Egan TwitterUUP#s Julie-Anne Corr-Johnston reacts to her poster being defaced with blue paint FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueConnie Egan and Andrew Muir had their photographs defaced on election posters throughout parts of Bangor this week. Credit: Connie Egan TwitterNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailAlliance councillor Connie Egan has poked fun at the vandalism of her election poster in parts of Bangor, joking that it’s a “terrible” show of “artwork”.The North Down Assembly candidate shared photos of the ruined posters, which show pictures of both Ms Egan and her colleague Andrew Muir. Their faces have been completely scored out by black and red colourings, to which Ms Egan wrote: “Disappointed to see the terrible artwork on display in parts of Bangor. North Down is an area full of local talent, I know you can do better than this!”Many online users shared their support for the Bangor West councillor, with one writing: “See it as a positive, you are rattling someone#s cage.”Another joked: “Your picture isn#t that bad, solid  for effort, the lines bring it to a solid  though.”Disappointed to see the terrible artwork on display in parts of Bangor. North Down is an area full of local talent, I know you can do better than this! pic UYMRVVdyT— Connie EganApril , Last summer, Ms Egan made headlines by repurposing her old council election posters to Ulster Wildle, who transformed them into footprint tunnels for the local hedgehog population.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The tunnels are used in the ongoing Irish Hedgehog Survey, which aims to help researchers gain full knowledge of the ious habitats of hedgehogs here and across the island of Ireland.Another Assembly candidate who hasn’t been taking graffiti artists too seriously is the Ulster Unionist Party#s candidate for North Belfast, former PUP councillor Julie-Anne Corr-Johnston. On Tuesday, she managed to turn the tables when a poster of hers was defaced with blue paint. In response, Ms Corr-Johnston posted a picture of her face on social media covered in blue paint with the caption: Today#s look is inspired by anonymous.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseUUP#s Julie-Anne Corr-Johnston reacts to her poster being defaced with blue paint FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueUUP#s Julie-Anne Corr-Johnston reacts to her poster being defaced with blue paintSince parties have began their latest campaigns for the upcoming  Assembly elections, the PSNI have received numerous reports of theft and damage of election material across Northern Ireland.Nearly a fortnight ago, the TUV’s West Tyrone candidate Trevor Clarke said posters belonging to him, which were on display close to Edwards Primary School in Castlederg, were stolen.Mr Clarke said the “unlawful interference” would not deter his campaign and also challenged others “across the political spectrum” to condemn the incident.The SDLP’s Charlotte Carson recently had her poster set on fire at Cyprus Avenue in east Belfast too, and her colleague, Strangford candidate Conor Houston also had more than  posters stolen in the Newtownards area near the end of last month.Meanwhile, Sinn Fein MLA Jemma Dolan confirmed a number of her election posters in Enniskillen had been stolen and set alight.The Fermanagh and south Tyrone MLA wrote on social media: “Election posters are part of our democratic culture. Removing them is doing nothing but attempting to interfere with democracy.”Read MoreTUV hit out at ‘juvenile attack on democracy’ as election posters stolen in Co TyroneRelated topicsAlliance title: independent candidate claire sugden using her artistic flair for election material
story: One of Claire Sugden’s posters. Credit: Claire Sugden FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueOne of Claire Sugden’s posters. Credit: Claire SugdenNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailAssembly candidate Claire Sugden has revealed how she has been working into the wee small hours creating her own election posters, leaflets and social media imagery.Despite having no formal graphics training, the former East Londonderry MLA designs and writes all of her own election material — something she has been doing since she first stood for Stormont six years ago.“It saves me a considerable amount of money and it’s something I enjoy,” explained the independent unionist and former justice minister. “Whenever I was at the age when I was deciding what it was I wanted to do with my le, it was either politics or art. I ended up going down the political route, so it’s kind of nice that when it comes to election times, I can exercise that other side of things.“I have an A-level in art and that’s it. It’s all self-taught. My husband is a computer games artist, so I take a lot of advice from him, but a lot of it is Googling how to do things and, I think, having a bit of an eye for design anyway. None of it is perfect, I’m sure someone who is qualied and experienced in this field would be able to pull up something quicker and a lot more eye-catching, but I’m pleased with the way it turns out.”The Coleraine woman said she spent a few days last week “going round the constituency getting some photographs just to get nice fresh images for the literature”, but overall she’s kept to the same colour scheme and theme for her election content since she first stood in .“It can take a while, but sitting down I can get into a bit of a zone with it. You can find me maybe starting it at pm and still sitting until am in the morning because I’m on a bit of a roll with it. There’s other days when I get a bit of a block and that’s usually the days where you’re under pressure and trying to make deadlines for printers.”She joked: “If the election doesn’t go my way, maybe I have another career!”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumIt’s time to send election posters to the scrapheapEimear McGovernThere is no need for them and they’re not good for environmentExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseScrap: with social media and ious outlets there is no need for election posters. Credit: Graham Baalham-Curry FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueScrap: with social media and ious outlets there is no need for election posters. Credit: Graham Baalham-CurryApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailYou can’t drink your morning coffee without an audience and as you walk down the road you are watched from all angles, both geometrically and politically.That’s right — election season is upon us and as a result, the faces of your local politicians on poster after poster are becoming more familiar than the heartthrobs we had on our walls as teenagers.It is one staple of election campaigns that has been around for decades,not centuries, and while there’s some sport initially in comparing the tenets of graphic design, colour schemes and haircutsof our political representatives, when you sit and think about it, is this something that’s really needed in this day and age As a journalist, I’m probablymore familiar with Northern Ireland’s politicians than the average person, given my job involves thinking, talking and writing about them on a daily basis. As such, I don’t often need a reminder of who there is to vote for in my constituency or what parties they stand for. I’ll admit that an election poster is certainly an easy way to raise awareness of, on a basic level, exactly who represents or wants to represent you.But after seeing the same person staring at me five times before I had crossed a single bridge in Coleraine where I live the other day, I started to wonder do posters influence how people vote — or are posters just a habit, one which may not serve the most purpose but indicates you have a dog in the fight Read MoreIndependent candidate Claire Sugden using her artistic flair for election materialThe ironic thing is that maybe posters mean much more to the smaller parties and independents with comparably smaller budgets to the more prominent frontrunners. For them, it’s more of a stretch to measure up the level of postering and the legwork it takes displayed by other parties but who worry they won’t get as much attentionthey don’t appear to have parity in terms of faces on streets.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Often described as CorriBoard posters, many of those massive signs you see on our streets and roads are made from one of the dirtiest words of our time — plastic. While the materials can sometimes be upcycled, it is suggested they will take hundreds of years to degrade, long after the politicians whose faces on which they featured and possibly even the parties they represented have departed this fine earth.It’s true that they do have benefits. They are immune to hackers which have plagued recent international elections . Not everyone has top class internet access so it does keep demographics informed. There’s no question that they send a message to voters and a reminder that an election is taking place — andyour local MLA hasn’t fixed that pothole on your road, you will know just the face to ask when they come a-canvassing.Green Party NI politician Mal O’Hara has joined some of his international colleagues in favouring a system seen in Europe where paper posters are erected in certain spaces only, instead of being festooned on every available surface. But this approach isn’t favoured by some larger parties who are able to spread their resources more widely and want to be able to show that. And so, without any wider consensus, the great poster parade marches on even in  when the word on all of our lips is the environment and many of us are kept awake at night wondering what sort of a world it is we’re leaving behind for the next generation and the one after that.What is the alternative  Some may argue it’s already here, and it’s called social media, where most views are shared and heard and your popularity isn’t always just down to what party backs you, but how well you use your voice. There’s also mainstream media via the television, news sites and newspapers as well as the radio. And for those who have access to neither, there’s canvassing — and feel free to reject those shiny leaflets which usually take a short trip to the bin in favour of a chat instead.Or why not make use of the screens in Belfast city centre or in shopping centres to instead display candidates posters on a revolving basis, on the proviso that these screens and devices would have to be made more widely available in our towns and villages Some may disregard these suggestions but surely there must be another way, instead of risking damage to the environment and obscuring our beautul landscape on this island with these massive posters cropping up at regular intervals.Whatever your thoughts on posters, the discourse around them doesn’t end after the election unfortunately. And while you might find the face of a local politician peaking out from behind a hedge or unlucky enough to be placed atop a bonfire, you will also be treated to the crowdsourcing operation that is your local politician asking you to make them aware of any forlorn final poster still lingering on our streets. Or at the very least, a photo of them with clippers in hand, telling all they are out and about removing their posters, sent to the rubbish heap, after election season comes to an end.Related title: northern ireland assembly election 2022 people have a choice to attend polling station if covid positive electoral
story: Northern Ireland will soon go to the polls. Credit: Liam McBurney FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNorthern Ireland will soon go to the polls. Credit: Liam McBurneyChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPeople who wake up on the day of the Assembly Election in May and test positive for Covid- or have symptoms “may still go to vote”, according to the Electoral Office.Virginia McVea, from the Electoral Office for Northern Ireland told BBC’s Good Morning Ulster show that the rules around the issue had been directed by the government.The chief electoral officer also confirmed there has been no change in the rules around postal and proxy voting to make allowances for Covid- and stressed that anyone who is vulnerable or has been shielding throughout the pandemic should apply by the deadline of April .When asked what people should dothey wake up on May  with symptoms or having tested positive for Covid, Ms McVea said “government has directed that you have a choice”.You can go to the polling station we are asking you to take every precaution,” she told BBC Radio Ulster.For others going into the polling station you will see all of the normal precautions that have come in everywhere  - perspex, automatic hand sanitisers, ventilation.You don’t lose your vote because what government has directed is that people who test positive or who have symptoms may still go to vote.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreWhen is the Northern Ireland Assembly Election   The key dates and all you need to know about how to voteThat is as the legislation sits. I am dutybound to communicate that to people, people will have dferent views on that, but that is what the government has directed. That is your choice.”Polling day at the forthcoming Assembly Election begins from am on Thursday May , with polling stations remaining open until pm that evening.When askedpeople can apply for a postal or proxy vote ahead of time in the event they do have Covid-, Ms McVea confirmed this was not possible.Anyone is free to apply [for a postal vote] but what must happen is it can’t be an entirely hypothetical situation. If someone has been shielding or there are mental health issue or other vulnerabilities, it would be reasonable at this point to say ‘I couldn’t expose myself to risk’,” she added.Government has directed that in Northern Ireland the normal absent vote legislation should apply, so there has been no change in Northern Ireland to make allowance for Covid and that means April  is such an important deadline for anyone who has been shielding or who is frail or vulnerable.”The Department of Health has been approached for comment.Most ReadBallycastle is Northern Ireland’s best place to
